Add a plane above the sofa. Use loop cuts to make sure you have square quads, then subdivide several times to get enough faces for the cloth simulator. Ctrl-A to apply rotation and scaling, then UV unwrap the plane.
Fold the plane onto itself so the simulator will collide with itself. Add Subdivision modifier and set for smooth surface.

Turn on Self Collision and set the Quality to 1 - this prevents the cloth from going through itself. Set Friction to 80 to prevent the cloth from sliding off the sofa. Use the Cotton preset.
Run the simulation. Stop the animation at a point you are happy with, then freeze the simulation by applying the subsurf and the cloth simulator. This turns the plane into a regular mesh.



With the Image Texture node lode the texture 101.png:




Add the Texture Coordinate node and a Mapping node to scale down the size of the pattern (30 on x, 15 on y â€” this is because the texture is rectangular).



Add a Color Ramp node to change the color of the texture. Left side changes the foreground, right side the background.



Add a Fresnel node and a MixRGB node. Connect the ColorRamp node to Color 1 on the MixRGB node and the Fresnel node to the Fac on the MixRGB node. Change Color2 to something that looks good in the result. The Fresnel node makes the blanket look more like cloth.
